title: Deepwater & Subsea Advanced Operations
description: Deepwater drilling adds complexity through water depth, subsea equipment, and riser systems. This module covers advanced subsea operations beyond basic IWCF content - focusing on operational decision-making in real scenarios.
objectives: Make time-critical EDS decisions under pressure
Manage riser margin and CLFL in actual operations

keyTopics.content: Emergency Disconnect Sequence requires rapid assessment: How much time? What's the pipe position? Is the well controlled? With 15+ minutes, optimize. With <5 minutes, execute regardless of pipe position. The decision tree must be pre-planned and practiced.

Riser margin protects against riser loss. In 648m water, if the riser parts, you lose MW and gain seawater density in that column. Your mud below must compensate. Monitor riser margin as pore pressure increases with depth.

Choke line friction loss affects all subsea well control. CLFL must be measured at kill rate with current mud weight. It's added to ICP and included in FCP calculations. Wrong CLFL = wrong pressures = failed kill or formation damage.

Gas that migrates above the BOP into the riser is no longer controlled by the choke. It will expand rapidly as it rises through decreasing hydrostatic. Diverter operations, controlled circulation through riser booster line, or riser disconnection may be required.

The BOP is 648m away - you can't just walk over and fix it. ROV intervention capability, acoustic backup, deadman/autoshear systems, and redundancy are critical. Know your backup systems and test them.

operationalPrinciples: Time is compressed in subsea emergencies - decide fast
Know your CLFL before you need it
Riser margin erodes as pore pressure increases - recalculate
Practice EDS until the sequence is automatic
Backup systems only work if you test them
